msgSnippet: Not to be offensive, but this has been covered extensively throughout this list.  Migrate to assertTrue... -jason ... http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/

Subject: RE: [junit] The upcoming "assert" keyword in JDK 1.4
Date: Wed, 3 Oct 2001 16:01:33 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
X-WSS-ID: 17A5B117250330-01-01
Content-Type: text/plain; 
 charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

Not to be offensive, but this has been covered extensively throughout this
list.  Migrate to assertTrue...

-jason

    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Green, Noah [mailto:noah.green@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, October 03, 2001 3:59 PM
    > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    > Subject: [junit] The upcoming "assert" keyword in JDK 1.4
    > 
    > 
    > 
    > Preliminary research by me and co-workers indicates that 
    > Sun is adding an
    > assertion facility to JDK 1.4.  If this happens the way 
    > it says in the
    > documentation, "assert" will become a reserved keyword in 
    > the Java language.
    > Here is the Sun page detailing the new assertion facility:
    > http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/docs/guide/lang/assert.html
    > Note that it seems this is already in the beta of JDK 1.4.  
    > 
    > The document also details ways of turning off assertions, 
    > including the fact
    > that you must use a special setting at compile time in order
    > for assertions to work at all:
    > http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/docs/guide/lang/assert.html#compiling
    > 
    > The question is whether not using this compile-time 
    > setting frees up the
    > "assert" keyword for use as a method name.  My fear is that it
    > does not.  
    > 
    > This could definitely cramp our style, to put it mildly.  
    > Anyone know any
    > more about this issue?
    > 
    > Thanks,
    > Noah Green
    > 
    > 
    >
